717159f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Park Row
717159f-a.text:
Broadway and Park Row convergence as photographec north-
ward from the old Astor House lying between Vesey and
Barclay Streets. Broadway is to the left and Park Row
is on the right. Note the absence of the old U. S. Post
Office at the apex in the Park.
About 1860e
American Studio, photo
87 Nassau Street, N.Y.7.
Gift of Urbrock Collection
REPRODUCTION RICRTE UNRNOwN

717150f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Park Row
717150f-a.text:
Broadway North from cor. of Park Row E Broadway -
Barnumus Museum 1863 - Earliest known photo
of this section ofN.Y. by drady -
Recruiting Station for the Civil War
Photo By
Brown Brothers
22c0 West 42nd St.
New York City

717151f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Park Row
717151f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, north from but not including Park Row.
This picture is one of the first photos taken of New York City.
It was made from a wet plate negative.
About 1863.
Brown Brothers.

717162f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Park Row
717162f-a.text:
Broadway &. Park Row, north from their convergence at Vesey
Street, showing the old U. S. Post Offiee at the apex of City
Hall Park. Note the completion or roof repairs. At the left
is the Astor House, occupying the Broadway frontage from Vesey
to Barclay Street's..
Ne6 ~ E2S
About 1880
Gift of 'rbrock Collection

722430f-a.title: Manhattan: Park Row - Broadway
722430f-a.text:
Park Row, south from the Brooklyn Bridge, to and including Broadway.
The view shows in the foreground, the new (then) pedestrian approach to
the Brooklyn Bridge Station of the Second and Third Aves., Elevated.
Adjoining same is the Pulitzer Building, with the spire of the Tribune
Building overshadowing the Times Building, on the right. Iu the distant
background, at the southern extremity of Park Row, at Broadway, is ob-
served St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Chapel. Directly on the right.
is the Hall of Records, built as a City Jail about 1775.
About 1880.

722431f-a.title: Manhattan: Park Row - Broadway
722431f-a.text:
Park Row, aouth from the Brooklyn Bridge, to and including Broadway.
The view shows on the extreme right, the old Hall of Records, with the
City Hall further westward. In the direct center, is the old U.S.P.O..
with the Times Building on the opposite side of the street. At the head of
Park Row, at Broadway, appears St. Paul's Church and Grounds. Note the
horse drawn cars. Bridge shown, in the the foreground, Was an extension
from the Brooklyn Bridge Station of the Manhattan Elevated Lines.
About 18B4.
New York Edison Co.

717118f.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Barclay Street
717118f.text:
V S J
Broadway,North West corner,Barclay to Vesey Streets,
and shouing the old Astor House,since demolished and St.Paul's
Chapel.
(2)The same,closer view.
About 1885.
Urbrock Collection,
May not be reproduced.

717136f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Barclay Street
717136f-a.text:
Broadway,West Side,between Barclay and Vesey Streets,
showing the old Astor House.
About 1885.
Urbrock Collection,
Credit Line Imperative.

717138f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Barclay Street
717138f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, at Barclay Street, showing the
sites pf the future Transportation and Woolworth Bldgs.
The former rose in 1926 at the S. W. corner that now is
the northerly half of the old Astor Hotse. The severel
structures at the right forming the block frontage from
Barclay iitreet to Park Place will be removed in 1912
for the distinctive Woolworth Building.
About 1890
Roege, photo
H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

717117f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Park Row
717117f-a.text:
Broadway at Park Row.
"248. Astor House & St. Pauls, 1893.'

717145f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Barclay Street
717145f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, south from and including Barclay (foreground) to
Dey (extreme left) Streets, showing prominently the Aator House, which
occupies the block between Barclay and Vesey Streets. South of same,
on the Vesey to Fulton Streets block, appears St. Pauls P.E. Chapel
and Grounds. The spired structure, in the same direction is the 11-story
Western Union Building, No. 195 Broadway, at the N.W. corner of Dey
Street. Shown on the right are Nos. 229 and 231 Broadway, at and adjoin-
ing the N.Wu. corner of Barclay Street.
June 3, 1904.
Brown Brothers.

717119f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Barclay Street
717119f-a.text:
Broadway, south from Barclay Street, showing this thorough-
fare below City Hall Park. At the right is the old Astor House,
occupying the frontage from Barclay to Vesey Street's. Inthe
block below, Vesey to Fulton St's., 1s St. Pauls Chapel. The old
Evening Mail and the towering Singer Building overshadow these.
Dn the left is the St. Paul Building on the old P. T. Barnum site.
Park Row converges with Broadway at this point; transportation
is provided by the Third Avenue R. R. Co. on this artery, and a
atreet car of same appears thereupon.
About 1910
Gift of Urbrock Collection

717172f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Barclay Street
717172f-a.text:
7233 Broadway,showing the Woolworth Building,60 stories
high located at that site. The building has an elevation of
792 feet,
November 20th,I9I2.
Copyrighted by,
Underhill,
No Reproductions.

717170f-b.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Barclay Street
717170f-b.text:
Broadway, west side, from Barclay Street to Park Place,
showing the Woolworth Building at this location. Note the
constructional details atop the tower in both views. The
smaller view is obviously in a northward direction from the
old Western Union Building and includes the spire of St.
Pauls Chapel and the old Astor House in the toreground. At
the right is the old U. S. Post Office with a glimpse of
the City Hall above same. The 1 story Emigrant Industrid
Bank rises above the latter.
1912-3
International News Service
(larger view)
Gift or Urbrock Collection
REPRODUCTION RIORTS URENON
Gift of Urbrock Collection

717173f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Barclay Street
717173f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, at Barclay Street; and showing at the S.W. corner
the Transportation Building, with the Woolworth Building occupying the N.W.
corner. In the foreground, at the right, appears a portion of the dome
of the old Post Office Building.
About 1925.
NEG7EEG

722429f-b.text:

United 5tates Post Office Building which was erected in I869,
at a cost of Eight Millions of dollars. It was erected on EI
city lots,(portion of City Hall Park),that was ceded to theFederal

717174f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Barclay Street
717174f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, from Barclay Street (right) to
Park Place (left) showing the Woolworth Building at this
site. View is eastward from the air towards the East
River and its Brooklyn shore. City Hall Park is at the
left. Flanking the dominant structure are, the World,
the Tribune and the Park Row buildings. The old U. S.
Post Office buflding is obstructed from view.
About 1928
Copyrighted by
Major Hamilton Maxwell

717175f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Barclay Street
717175f-a.text:
229 to 237 Broadway, west side, from Barclay Street to Park Place,
showing the Woolworth Building as viewed southwestward through the arches
of the Municipal Building and aoross the City Hall and City Hall Park.
About 1930.
Ewing Galloway.

717176f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Barclay Street
717176f-a.text:
229 to 237 Broadway, west side, from Barclay Street to Park Place,
showing the Woolworth Building as viewed southwestward through the columns
of the Municipal Building and across the City Hall and City Hall Park.
about 1930.
Ewing Galloway.

718924f-b.title: Manhattan: Park Row - Broadway
718924f-b.text:
(1)
City Hall Park, as seen from the Municipal Building, and showing
City Hall between Park Row (left), and Broadway (right). Aoross the top
of the views, appears the Mail Street side of the old United States Post (  1
office.
June 3, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
NEdG : 2214
(2)
A similar view, and showing on the right, a portion of the Court
House, which fronts on Chambers Street; the northern boundry of the
park..
June 3, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

718924f-a.title: Manhattan: Park Row - Broadway
718924f-a.text:

717166f.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Park Row
717166f.text:
Broadway (leftl and Park Row (ricNtV above Vesey Street,
showing the old General Post Office and Federal Bldg. on
the day demolition actually startec on the outside. This
structure, erected about 63 years ago at a cost of 8,500,
000 is to be removed to allow City Hall Park to return to
its original contour. For a photo of same from the same
point of vantage (The N. f. Telephone &. Telegraph Bldg.)
see files under City Hall Park.
September 9, 1938
Robert A. Knudtsen
221 E. 31at St., N.Y.C.

717168f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Park Row
717168f-a.text:
Broadway (left) and Park Row (right), north from Ann Street,
showing demolition of the old U. S. Post Office. A portion of the
Woolworth Buildings forms the left margin.
1939
Alexander Alland
This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume
"Portrait of N. y.' by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.

717131f.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Barclay Street
717131f.text:
Broadway, south from Barclay Street (right), showing cables being
laid on the east side of this thoroughfare and slightly north of the
Astor House, which appears on the right. South of the latter is St.
Pauls Chapel.. On the left is a portion of the Post Office,gt thc
convergence of Broadway and Park Row. Across the latter are structures
on the east side of same, at Ann Street.
About 1890.

717171f-c.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Barclay Street
717171f-c.text:
229-237 Broadway, west side, from Barclay Street to Park
Place, showing at this location, the 55 story Woolworth Bldg.
The general direction is northward from a vantage point at
No. 165 Broadway (City Investing H1d2.) in views 1, 2, and 3.
View 4 is photographed from No. 30 Church Street. Broadway is
the thoroughfare clearly shown at the right. Note the spire
of St. Pauls Chapel, the quadrangular Astor House, the ornate
Post Office, City Hall Park and the white marble Sun (formerly
A. C. Stewarts) Building. The St. Paul ldg. ppears at the
right margin of views 1 and 3. Today, (1939) this view is
Nmore or less the same. The most radical change is the replace-
ment of the old Astor House by the 44 storied Transportation
Bldg. and the present demolition of the Post Office.
View 1 March 1912
2 June 1912
3January 19, 1917 NEG P~ S629
4August 11, 1925 N E, Ei W6IE
0ift of W. A. Lucas

717180f.text:

717182f-b.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Barclay Street
717182f-b.text:
(1)
220 to 259 Broadway, west side, north from Barclay (left) to Warren
(right) Streets, as viewed in a southwesterly direction from the
Municipal Building and across City Hall Park. Prominently shown are
the Transportation, Woolworth and New York Telephone Buildings all
silhouetted against the North (Hudson) River. In the left foreground
is the roof of the City Hall.
June 23, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, minus No. 258-259, the Rogers Peet Building, at the S.E.
corner of Warren Street. Shown in the left foreground of this view is
the old United States Post Office located in the southern tip of City
Hall Park.
June 12, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same, exclusive of the oolworth Building, No. 229-237 Broadway,
from Barclay Street to Park Place. On the right of this view appears
a 12-story structure, No. 260-261 Broadway, at the N.d. corner of
Warren Street, and a 5-story building, No. 265, adjoining same.
June 23, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
